org.chronos.chronodb.api

Interface IndexManager

  • All Known Implementing Classes:
    AbstractBackendDelegatingIndexManager, AbstractIndexManager, ChunkDbIndexManager, DocumentBasedIndexManager

    public interface IndexManager
    An IndexManager is a backend-agnostic facade for indexing in a ChronoDB.

    The responsibilities of an index manager include:

    • Management of registered Indexer instances
    • Performing indexing and re-indexing of the database
    • Evaluating ChronoDBQuery instances on the index

    Instances of this interface can be retrieved via ChronoDB.getIndexManager(). API users should not attempt to create an instance of a class that implements this interface manually.

    Implementation notes

    While an index manager implementation may be implemented specifically for a given backend, implementations are usually generic and the actual indexing backend is provided via an instance of DocumentBasedIndexManagerBackend. One example of such an approach is the DocumentBasedIndexManager.

    • Method Detail

      • getIndexNames

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getIndexNames()
        Returns the names of all known indices in an immutable set.
        Returns:
        An immutable view on all known index names.

      • removeIndex

        void removeIndex(java.lang.String indexName)
        Removes the index with the given name, including index structures and registered indexers.

        If the index with the given name does not exist, this method does nothing.

        If a specific indexer should be removed, please consider using removeIndexer(Indexer) instead.

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index to remove. Must not be null.

      • clearAllIndices

        void clearAllIndices()
        Clears all index information on all known indices and also removes all Indexers.

        This method effectively resets the index to an empty state and should be used with great care.

        WARNING: This operation cannot be undone!

      • addIndexer

        default void addIndexer(java.lang.String indexName,
                        Indexer<?> indexer)
        Adds the given indexer to the index with the given name.

        This method acts as an "umbrella" method for its other overloads, e.g. addIndexer(String, StringIndexer). Please note that this method will redirect to those other methods, and throw a ChronoDBIndexingException if no suitable overload was found.

        Please note that for any index, there must be at most one indexer that accepts any given object. If there are multiple indexers on the same index that accept a given object upon insertion, a IndexerConflictException is thrown when the object is inserted.

        Adding an indexer dirties the index. Consider calling reindexAll() when all changes to the indexers are complete.

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index to which the indexer should be added. Must not be null. If there is no index with the given name yet, it is created on-the-fly.
        indexer - The indexer to add. Must not be null.

      • addIndexer

        void addIndexer(java.lang.String indexName,
                StringIndexer indexer)
        Adds the given indexer to the index with the given name.

        Please note that for any index, there must be at most one indexer that accepts any given object. If there are multiple indexers on the same index that accept a given object upon insertion, an IndexerConflictException is thrown when the object is inserted.

        If multiple indexers are registered to the same index name, then all indexers must have the same type (i.e. you cannot mix string and long indexers in the same index).

        Adding an indexer dirties the index. Consider calling reindexAll() when all changes to the indexers are complete.

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index to which the indexer should be added. Must not be null. If there is no index with the given name yet, it is created on-the-fly.
        indexer - The indexer to add. Must not be null.

      • addIndexer

        void addIndexer(java.lang.String indexName,
                LongIndexer indexer)
        Adds the given indexer to the index with the given name.

        Please note that for any index, there must be at most one indexer that accepts any given object. If there are multiple indexers on the same index that accept a given object upon insertion, an IndexerConflictException is thrown when the object is inserted.

        If multiple indexers are registered to the same index name, then all indexers must have the same type (i.e. you cannot mix string and long indexers in the same index).

        Adding an indexer dirties the index. Consider calling reindexAll() when all changes to the indexers are complete.

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index to which the indexer should be added. Must not be null. If there is no index with the given name yet, it is created on-the-fly.
        indexer - The indexer to add. Must not be null.

      • addIndexer

        void addIndexer(java.lang.String indexName,
                DoubleIndexer indexer)
        Adds the given indexer to the index with the given name.

        Please note that for any index, there must be at most one indexer that accepts any given object. If there are multiple indexers on the same index that accept a given object upon insertion, an IndexerConflictException is thrown when the object is inserted.

        If multiple indexers are registered to the same index name, then all indexers must have the same type (i.e. you cannot mix string and long indexers in the same index).

        Adding an indexer dirties the index. Consider calling reindexAll() when all changes to the indexers are complete.

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index to which the indexer should be added. Must not be null. If there is no index with the given name yet, it is created on-the-fly.
        indexer - The indexer to add. Must not be null.

      • removeIndexer

        void removeIndexer(Indexer<?> indexer)
        Removes the given indexer from all indices where it is used.

        If the indexer is not in use, this method does nothing.

        Removing an indexer dirties the index. Consider calling reindexAll() when all changes to the indexers are complete.

        Parameters:
        indexer - The indexer to remove. Must not be null.

      • getIndexers

        java.util.Set<Indexer<?>> getIndexers()
        Returns an unmodifiable view on the indexers which are currently in use.
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable view on the indexers. May be empty, but never null.

      • getStringIndexers

        default java.util.Set<StringIndexer> getStringIndexers()
        Returns an unmodifiable view on the StringIndexers which are currently in use.
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable view on the indexers. May be empty, but never null.

        Returns:

        Returns:

      • getIndexersByIndexName

        java.util.Map<java.lang.String,java.util.Set<Indexer<?>>> getIndexersByIndexName()
        Returns a mapping from index name to the indexers which are in use by that index.
        Returns:
        An unmodifiable mapping from index name to indexers. May be empty, but never null.

      • reindex

        @Deprecated
void reindex(java.lang.String indexName)
        Deprecated. In Chronos 0.6.9 and later, simply use reindexAll().
        Re-indexes the index with the given name.

        This operation will force a re-index. Re-indexing is an expensive operation. Furthermore, re-indexing is an exclusive operation that does not permit any concurrent reads and/or writes on the database.

        If you are unsure if any index is dirty and requires re-indexing, please consider using reindexAll() instead.

        Parameters:
        indexName - The name of the index to re-index. Must not be null.

      • reindexAll

        void reindexAll()
        Re-indexes all dirty indices.

        Note that this is not a forced re-index. Only dirty indices will be re-indexed.

        Re-indexing is an expensive operation. Furthermore, re-indexing is an exclusive operation that does not permit any concurrent reads and/or writes on the database.

      • isReindexingRequired

        boolean isReindexingRequired()
        Checks if any index is dirty and requires re-indexing.

        If this method returns true, please consider calling reindexAll() to create a clean index.

        Returns:
        true if at least one index is dirty and requires re-indexing, otherwise false.

      • getDirtyIndices

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getDirtyIndices()
        Returns an immutable set of all index names that are currently referring to dirty indices.
        Returns:
        The immutable set of the names of dirty indices. May be empty, but never null.

      • index

        void index(java.util.Map<ChronoIdentifier,org.apache.commons.lang3.tuple.Pair<java.lang.Object,java.lang.Object>> identifierToOldAndNewValue)
        Indexes the given key-value pairs.

        This method is not considered part of the public API. Clients must not call this method directly!

        Parameters:
        identifierToOldAndNewValue - The map of changed ChronoIdentifiers to their respective old and new values to index. Must not be null, may be empty.

      • queryIndex

        java.util.Set<java.lang.String> queryIndex(long timestamp,
                                           Branch branch,
                                           java.lang.String keyspace,
                                           SearchSpecification<?> searchSpec)
        Queries the index by providing a value description.
        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp at which the query takes place. Must not be negative.
        branch - The branch to evaluate the query in. Must not be null. Must refer to an existing branch.
        keyspace - The keyspace to evaluate the query in. Must not be null.
        searchSpec - The search specification to fulfill. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        The set of keys that have a value assigned that matches the given description. May be empty, but never null.

      • evaluate

        java.util.Iterator<QualifiedKey> evaluate(long timestamp,
                                          Branch branch,
                                          ChronoDBQuery query)
        Evaluates the given ChronoDBQuery.
        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp at which the evaluation takes place. Must not be negative.
        branch - The branch to evaluate the query in. Must not be null.
        query - The query to run. Must not be null. Must have been optimized before calling this method.
        Returns:
        An iterator on the keys that have values assigned which match the query. May be empty, but never null.

      • evaluateCount

        long evaluateCount(long timestamp,
                   Branch branch,
                   ChronoDBQuery query)
        Evaluates the given ChronoDBQuery.
        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp at which the evaluation takes place. Must not be negative.
        branch - The branch to evaluate the query in. Must not be null.
        query - The query to run. Must not be null. Must have been optimized before calling this method.
        Returns:
        The number of key-value pairs in the database that match the given query. May be zero, but never negative.

      • rollback

        void rollback(long timestamp)
        Performs a rollback on the index to the given timestamp.

        This affects all branches. Any index entries that belong to later timestamps will be removed.

        Parameters:
        timestamp - The timestamp to roll back to. Must not be negative.
        See Also:
        rollback(Branch, long), rollback(Branch, long, Set)

      • rollback

        void rollback(Branch branch,
              long timestamp,
              java.util.Set<QualifiedKey> keys)
        Performs a rollback on the index in the given branch to the given timestamp, for the given set of keys only.

        All index entries that are unrelated to the given keys will remain untouched by this operation, even if these entries were added and/or modified after the given timestamp.

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to roll back. Must not be null.
        timestamp - The timestamp to roll back to. Must not be negative.
        keys - The keys to roll back. Must not be null. If this set is empty, this method returns immediately and has no effect.
        See Also:
        rollback(long)

      • rollback

        void rollback(Branch branch,
              long timestamp)
        Performs a rollback on the index in the given branch to the given timestamp.

        This operation will affect all entries in the given branch after the given timestamp.

        Parameters:
        branch - The branch to roll back. Must not be null.
        timestamp - The timestamp to roll back to. Must not be negative.
        See Also:
        rollback(long), rollback(Branch, long, Set)

      • clearQueryCache

        void clearQueryCache()
        Clears the internal query cache, if query result caching is enabled.

        If query result caching is disabled, this method does nothing.
